utterances: I see.
So, otherwise, they would just be receiving an unemployment check.
They would be receiving a check.
But at the end of the day, they wouldn't be able to be providing anything back to the community.
How many people do you estimate have you put to work now?
Right now, there's probably between 300 and 310 that's gone to work.
And how many people live in the county total?
How drastically have you cut unemployment now?
Well, we've come down from 27 to 22.
But I think whenever we see the next month's unemployment numbers, I think we'll be down into the (unintelligible).
But when the unemployment rate reach 27 percent, you didn't really have to the time to sort of think about a big infrastructure project.
And you didn't have the luxury to wait for tenders and projects to be proposed.
You just had to get it out there.
I had to get the money out.

We would certainly love to see a long-term project like improvements to the roads or something that something that either put people to work on today and still have benefit from it 40, 50 years down the road.
But since we didn't have anything that was already in the pipeline, you know, this was the only thing that we had that could get the people back to work in the masses.
The stimulus bill was controversial, particularly in parts of the South.
Can you understand the concern of some governors in the South who have tried to refuse some of the stimulus money for fear of its impact on the federal deficit?
Well, yes - now, I didn't design the stimulus plan.
And had it been mine, there would have been some changes.
But this is a plan that we have so it wasn't what I had originally envisioned for the stimulus plan, but I am thankful for the investment that has been made.
How long can you sustain it?
I mean, what happens after this program ends?
Well, what this has done is given us an opportunity to live to fight another battle.
Right.
We've got until next September to continue our efforts to try to bring manufacturing or service type jobs that will have a long-term effect.
So, so far it seems to be working, huh?
It's working good for now.
Before the additional workers and the additional investment and equipment, the Armstrong Pie Company was making around 3,000 pies a week.
They've been able to take it to the point they're making around 3,000 a day now.
So a pretty significant increase.
Do you eat one pretty regularly?
Try to.
Which is your favorite?
Strawberry.
Highly recommend it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(Soundbite of music)
John Carroll is the mayor of Perry County, Tennessee.
Mayor Carroll, thank you so much.
I appreciate your time and I appreciate the opportunity.
From NPR News, this is All Things Considered.
I'm Michele Norris.
And I'm Melissa Block.
Coconut cream pie and the now ubiquitous Joe the Plumber were mentioned on the presidential campaign trail today.
Barack Obama held a rally in Roanoke, Virginia, where he told the story of a recent visit to a diner in Georgetown, Ohio.
The owner is a die-hard Republican.
Obama said after he got his piece of coconut cream pie, he asked the owner, how's business?
(Soundbite of Barack Obama speech)
He said, not so good.
Said my customers can't afford to eat out right now.
I said, well, I'm just curious, who's been running the economy for the last eight years?
(Soundbite of crowd cheering)
He said, I guess the Republicans have.
I said, if you just keep hitting your head against the wall over and over again, and it starts to hurt.
At some point, do you stop hitting it against the wall?
(Soundbite of laughter)
He said, I guess that would make sense.
I said, you might want to try the Democrats for a change.
(Soundbite of crowd cheering)
We can't do any worst.
John McCain urged his supporters on at a rally in Miami, and he again referred to Joe, the plumber from Ohio who had asked Obama if he'd make him pay more in taxes.
(Soundbite of John McCain speech)
Senator Obama says that he wanted to spread your wealth around.
(Soundbite of crowd booing)
Well, I think that with - like a lot of things, it takes time.
I think that - interestingly, I think President Obama and this particular White House has some credibility since Obama's our first high-tech, you know, president with his BlackBerry.

But - interestingly, you mentioned - leading to the government because last week, the New York Times had a story about how information that the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration had put together back in 2003, they had a proposal to study 10,000 drivers for the risks of using cell phones while at the wheel.

They had also, by then, had compiled way enough data to want to put out a serious warning to governors to make sure that whatever laws they put in place for cell phone use while driving, that it did not differentiate from hands-free because all the - most of the studies show that hands-free cell phones are no more safe than handheld.
So the, you know, the government has had actually, unfortunately, a role in depressing the dangers of cell phone use while driving.
And I think this represents a great opportunity to - for the government to put cell phones right at the same category of safety as drunk-driving and seatbelts.
All right, let's take a call from Sally in Oklahoma City.
Hi, Sally.
Hi.
Go ahead.
Well, I just wanted to say that I think that if it was a federal law, I would certainly think twice before picking up my phone.
I, personally, have driven through two or three red lights…
Really?
…while talking on my phone.
You know, it's like you're - because it was a situation where I was talking about something that was very emotional and I've totally forgot that I was behind the wheel.
I was in the conversation.
